User space can use this option to indicate to the kernel that the fdb entry is in use. self means the address is associated with the port drivers fdb. Usually hardware. master means the address is associated with master devices fdb. router means the destination address is associated with a router. Note that it's valid if the referenced device is a VXLAN type device and has route shortcircuit enabled. Defaults to self.
Specifies the name or index of the outgoing interface for the VXLAN device driver to reach the remote VXLAN tunnel endpoint. Defaults to unset.

refsect1.title: [BridgeMDB] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [BridgeMDB] section manages the multicast membership entries forwarding database table of a port and accepts the following keys. Specify several [BridgeMDB] sections to configure several permanent multicast membership entries.

listitem.para: Specifies the IPv4 or IPv6 multicast group address to add. This setting is mandatory.
The VLAN ID for the new entry. Valid ranges are 0 (no VLAN) to 4094. Optional, defaults to 0.

refsect1.title: [LLDP] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [LLDP] section manages the Link Layer Discovery Protocol (LLDP) and accepts the following keys:

listitem.para: When configured, the specified Manufacturer Usage Descriptions (MUD) URL will be sent in LLDP packets. The syntax and semantics are the same as for MUDURL= in the [DHCPv4] section described above.
The MUD URLs received via LLDP packets are saved and can be read using the sd_lldp_neighbor_get_mud_url() function.

refsect1.title: [CAN] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [CAN] section manages the Controller Area Network (CAN bus) and accepts the following keys:

listitem.para: The bitrate of CAN device in bits per second. The usual SI prefixes (K, M) with the base of 1000 can be used here. Takes a number in the range 1…4294967295.
Optional sample point in percent with one decimal (e.g. 75%, 87.5%) or permille (e.g. 875‰).
The bitrate and sample point for the data phase, if CAN-FD is used. These settings are analogous to the BitRate= and SamplePoint= keys.

Takes a boolean. When yes, CAN-FD mode is enabled for the interface. Note, that a bitrate and optional sample point should also be set for the CAN-FD data phase using the DataBitRate= and DataSamplePoint= keys.
Takes a boolean. When yes, non-ISO CAN-FD mode is enabled for the interface. When unset, the kernel's default will be used.

Automatic restart delay time. If set to a non-zero value, a restart of the CAN controller will be triggered automatically in case of a bus-off condition after the specified delay time. Subsecond delays can be specified using decimals (e.g. 0.1s) or a ms or us postfix. Using infinity or 0 will turn the automatic restart off. By default automatic restart is disabled.
Takes a boolean. When yes, the termination resistor will be selected for the bias network. When unset, the kernel's default will be used.
Takes a boolean. When yes, three samples (instead of one) are used to determine the value of a received bit by majority rule. When unset, the kernel's default will be used.

Takes a boolean. When yes, reporting of CAN bus errors is activated (those include single bit, frame format, and bit stuffing errors, unable to send dominant bit, unable to send recessive bit, bus overload, active error announcement, error occurred on transmission). When unset, the kernel's default will be used. Note: in case of a CAN bus with a single CAN device, sending a CAN frame may result in a huge number of CAN bus errors.

Takes a boolean. When yes, listen-only mode is enabled. When the interface is in listen-only mode, the interface neither transmit CAN frames nor send ACK bit. Listen-only mode is important to debug CAN networks without interfering with the communication or acknowledge the CAN frame. When unset, the kernel's default will be used.

refsect1.title: [QDisc] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [QDisc] section manages the traffic control queueing discipline (qdisc).

listitem.para: Specifies the parent Queueing Discipline (qdisc). Takes one of clsact or ingress. This is mandatory.

refsect1.title: [NetworkEmulator] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [NetworkEmulator] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of the network emulator. It can be used to configure the kernel packet scheduler and simulate packet delay and loss for UDP or TCP applications, or limit the bandwidth usage of a particular service to simulate internet connections.

listitem.para: Specifies the fixed amount of delay to be added to all packets going out of the interface. Defaults to unset.
Specifies the chosen delay to be added to the packets outgoing to the network interface. Defaults to unset.
Specifies the maximum number of packets the qdisc may hold queued at a time. An unsigned integer in the range 0–4294967294. Defaults to 1000.
Specifies an independent loss probability to be added to the packets outgoing from the network interface. Takes a percentage value, suffixed with "%". Defaults to unset.
Specifies that the chosen percent of packets is duplicated before queuing them. Takes a percentage value, suffixed with "%". Defaults to unset.

refsect1.title: [TokenBucketFilter] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [TokenBucketFilter] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of token bucket filter (tbf).

listitem.para: Specifies the latency parameter, which specifies the maximum amount of time a packet can sit in the Token Bucket Filter (TBF). Defaults to unset.

Takes the number of bytes that can be queued waiting for tokens to become available. When the size is suffixed with K, M, or G, it is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset.

Specifies the size of the bucket. This is the maximum amount of bytes that tokens can be available for instantaneous transfer. When the size is suffixed with K, M, or G, it is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset.
Specifies the device specific bandwidth. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified bandwidth is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. Defaults to unset.
Takes the maximum depletion rate of the bucket. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. Defaults to unset.
Specifies the size of the peakrate bucket. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset.

refsect1.title: [PIE] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [PIE] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Proportional Integral controller-Enhanced (PIE).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the queue size in number of packets. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer in the range 1…4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [FlowQueuePIE] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [FlowQueuePIE] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Flow Queue Proportional Integral controller-Enhanced (fq_pie).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the queue size in number of packets. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer ranges 1 to 4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [StochasticFairBlue] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [StochasticFairBlue] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of stochastic fair blue (sfb).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the queue size in number of packets. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer in the range 0–4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [StochasticFairnessQueueing] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [StochasticFairnessQueueing] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of stochastic fairness queueing (sfq).

listitem.para: Specifies the interval in seconds for queue algorithm perturbation. Defaults to unset.

refsect1.title: [BFIFO] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [BFIFO] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Byte limited Packet First In First Out (bfifo).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit in bytes on the FIFO buffer size. The size limit prevents overflow in case the kernel is unable to dequeue packets as quickly as it receives them. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset and kernel default is used.

refsect1.title: [PFIFO] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [PFIFO] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Packet First In First Out (pfifo).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the number of packets in the FIFO queue. The size limit prevents overflow in case the kernel is unable to dequeue packets as quickly as it receives them. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer in the range 0–4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [PFIFOHeadDrop] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [PFIFOHeadDrop] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Packet First In First Out Head Drop (pfifo_head_drop).

listitem.para: As in [PFIFO] section.

refsect1.title: [PFIFOFast] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [PFIFOFast] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Packet First In First Out Fast (pfifo_fast).

refsect1.title: [CAKE] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [CAKE] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Common Applications Kept Enhanced (CAKE).

listitem.para: Specifies that bytes to be addeded to the size of each packet. Bytes may be negative. Takes an integer in the range from -64 to 256. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the shaper bandwidth. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [ControlledDelay] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [ControlledDelay] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of controlled delay (CoDel).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the queue size in number of packets. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer in the range 0–4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. Specifies the acceptable minimum standing/persistent queue delay. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. This is used to ensure that the measured minimum delay does not become too stale. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a boolean. This can be used to mark packets instead of dropping them. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. This sets a threshold above which all packets are marked with ECN Congestion Experienced (CE). Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [DeficitRoundRobinScheduler] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [DeficitRoundRobinScheduler] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Deficit Round Robin Scheduler (DRR).

refsect1.title: [DeficitRoundRobinSchedulerClass] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [DeficitRoundRobinSchedulerClass] section manages the traffic control class of Deficit Round Robin Scheduler (DRR).

listitem.para: Specifies the amount of bytes a flow is allowed to dequeue before the scheduler moves to the next class. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to the MTU of the interface.

refsect1.title: [EnhancedTransmissionSelection] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [EnhancedTransmissionSelection] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Enhanced Transmission Selection (ETS).

listitem.para: Specifies the number of bands. An unsigned integer in the range 1–16. This value has to be at least large enough to cover the strict bands specified through the StrictBands= and bandwidth-sharing bands specified in QuantumBytes=.
Specifies the number of bands that should be created in strict mode. An unsigned integer in the range 1–16.

Specifies the white-space separated list of quantum used in band-sharing bands. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. This setting can be specified multiple times. If an empty string is assigned, then the all previous assignments are cleared.

The priority map maps the priority of a packet to a band. The argument is a whitespace separated list of numbers. The first number indicates which band the packets with priority 0 should be put to, the second is for priority 1, and so on. There can be up to 16 numbers in the list. If there are fewer, the default band that traffic with one of the unmentioned priorities goes to is the last one. Each band number must be in the range 0…255. This setting can be specified multiple times. If an empty string is assigned, then the all previous assignments are cleared.

refsect1.title: [GenericRandomEarlyDetection] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [GenericRandomEarlyDetection] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Generic Random Early Detection (GRED).

listitem.para: Specifies the number of virtual queues. Takes an integer in the range 1…16. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Specifies the number of default virtual queue. This must be less than VirtualQueue=. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a boolean. It turns on the RIO-like buffering scheme. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [FairQueueingControlledDelay] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [FairQueueingControlledDelay] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of fair queuing controlled delay (FQ-CoDel).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the real queue size. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the limit on the total number of bytes that can be queued in this FQ-CoDel instance. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Specifies the number of flows into which the incoming packets are classified. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. Specifies the acceptable minimum standing/persistent queue delay. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. This is used to ensure that the measured minimum delay does not become too stale. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the number of bytes used as the "deficit" in the fair queuing algorithm timespan. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a boolean. This can be used to mark packets instead of dropping them. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. This sets a threshold above which all packets are marked with ECN Congestion Experienced (CE). Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [FairQueueing] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [FairQueueing] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of fair queue traffic policing (FQ).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the real queue size. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Specifies the hard limit on the maximum number of packets queued per flow. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the credit per dequeue RR round, i.e. the amount of bytes a flow is allowed to dequeue at once. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the initial sending rate credit, i.e. the amount of bytes a new flow is allowed to dequeue initially. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Specifies the maximum sending rate of a flow. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Specifies the size of the hash table used for flow lookups. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

Takes an unsigned integer. For packets not owned by a socket, fq is able to mask a part of hash and reduce number of buckets associated with the traffic. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a boolean, and enables or disables flow pacing. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.
Takes a timespan. This sets a threshold above which all packets are marked with ECN Congestion Experienced (CE). Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [TrivialLinkEqualizer] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [TrivialLinkEqualizer] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of trivial link equalizer (teql).

listitem.para: Specifies the interface ID N of teql. Defaults to 0. Note that when teql is used, currently, the module sch_teql with max_equalizers=N+1 option must be loaded before systemd-networkd is started.

refsect1.title: [HierarchyTokenBucket] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [HierarchyTokenBucket] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of hierarchy token bucket (htb).

listitem.para: Takes the minor id in hexadecimal of the default class. Unclassified traffic gets sent to the class. Defaults to unset.
Takes an unsigned integer. The DRR quantums are calculated by dividing the value configured in Rate= by RateToQuantum=.

refsect1.title: [HierarchyTokenBucketClass] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [HierarchyTokenBucketClass] section manages the traffic control class of hierarchy token bucket (htb).

listitem.para: Specifies the priority of the class. In the round-robin process, classes with the lowest priority field are tried for packets first.
Specifies how many bytes to serve from leaf at once. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024.
Specifies the maximum packet size we create. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024.

Takes an unsigned integer which specifies per-packet size overhead used in rate computations. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024.

Specifies the maximum rate this class and all its children are guaranteed. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. This setting is mandatory.

Specifies the maximum rate at which a class can send, if its parent has bandwidth to spare. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobits, Megabits, or Gigabits, respectively, to the base of 1000. When unset, the value specified with Rate= is used.

Specifies the maximum bytes burst which can be accumulated during idle period. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024.

Specifies the maximum bytes burst for ceil which can be accumulated during idle period. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024.

refsect1.title: [HeavyHitterFilter] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [HeavyHitterFilter] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Heavy Hitter Filter (hhf).

listitem.para: Specifies the hard limit on the queue size in number of packets. When this limit is reached, incoming packets are dropped. An unsigned integer in the range 0–4294967294. Defaults to unset and kernel's default is used.

refsect1.title: [QuickFairQueueing] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [QuickFairQueueing] section manages the queueing discipline (qdisc) of Quick Fair Queueing (QFQ).

refsect1.title: [QuickFairQueueingClass] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [QuickFairQueueingClass] section manages the traffic control class of Quick Fair Queueing (qfq).

listitem.para: Specifies the weight of the class. Takes an integer in the range 1…1023. Defaults to unset in which case the kernel default is used.

Specifies the maximum packet size in bytes for the class. When suffixed with K, M, or G, the specified size is parsed as Kilobytes, Megabytes, or Gigabytes, respectively, to the base of 1024. When unset, the kernel default is used.

refsect1.title: [BridgeVLAN] Section Options
refsect1.para: The [BridgeVLAN] section manages the VLAN ID configuration of a bridge port and accepts the following keys. Specify several [BridgeVLAN] sections to configure several VLAN entries. The VLANFiltering= option has to be enabled, see the [Bridge] section in systemd.netdev5.

listitem.para: The VLAN ID allowed on the port. This can be either a single ID or a range M-N. VLAN IDs are valid from 1 to 4094.

The VLAN ID specified here will be used to untag frames on egress. Configuring EgressUntagged= implicates the use of VLAN= above and will enable the VLAN ID for ingress as well. This can be either a single ID or a range M-N.

The Port VLAN ID specified here is assigned to all untagged frames at ingress. PVID= can be used only once. Configuring PVID= implicates the use of VLAN= above and will enable the VLAN ID for ingress as well.

example.title: Static network configuration
example.para: This brings interface enp2s0 up with a static address. The specified gateway will be used for a default route.

example.title: DHCP on ethernet links
example.para: This will enable DHCPv4 and DHCPv6 on all interfaces with names starting with en (i.e. ethernet interfaces).

example.title: IPv6 Prefix Delegation
example.para: This will enable DHCPv6-PD on the interface enp1s0 as an upstream interface where the DHCPv6 client is running and enp2s0 as a downstream interface where the prefix is delegated to. The delegated prefixes are distributed by IPv6 Router Advertisement on the downstream network.

example.title: A bridge with two enslaved links
example.para: This creates a bridge and attaches devices enp2s0 and wlp3s0 to it. The bridge will have the specified static address and network assigned, and a default route via the specified gateway will be added. The specified DNS server will be added to the global list of DNS resolvers.

example.programlisting:
# /etc/systemd/network/20-bridge-slave-interface-vlan.network [Match] Name=enp2s0
[Network] Bridge=bridge0
[BridgeVLAN] VLAN=1-32 PVID=42 EgressUntagged=42
[BridgeVLAN] VLAN=100-200
[BridgeVLAN] EgressUntagged=300-400
example.para: This overrides the configuration specified in the previous example for the interface enp2s0, and enables VLAN on that bridge port. VLAN IDs 1-32, 42, 100-400 will be allowed. Packets tagged with VLAN IDs 42, 300-400 will be untagged when they leave on this interface. Untagged packets which arrive on this interface will be assigned VLAN ID 42.

example.title: Various tunnels
example.para: This will bring interface ens1 up and create an IPIP tunnel, a SIT tunnel, a GRE tunnel, and a VTI tunnel using it.

example.title: A bond device
example.para: This will create a bond device bond1 and enslave the two devices with MAC addresses 52:54:00:e9:64:41 and 52:54:00:e9:64:42 to it. IPv6 DHCP will be used to acquire an address.

example.title: Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF)
example.para: Add the bond1 interface to the VRF master interface vrf1. This will redirect routes generated on this interface to be within the routing table defined during VRF creation. For kernels before 4.8 traffic won't be redirected towards the VRFs routing table unless specific ip-rules are added.

example.title: MacVTap
example.para: This brings up a network interface macvtap-test and attaches it to enp0s25.

example.title: A Xfrm interface with physical underlying device.
example.para: This creates a xfrm0 interface and binds it to the eth0 device. This allows hardware based ipsec offloading to the eth0 nic. If offloading is not needed, xfrm interfaces can be assigned to the lo device.
